Executive Summary - Coalgate/Tupelo Gas Plant

The following is a summary of the accident prevention program in place at the Coalgate/Tupelo Gas Plant (Coalgate/Tupelo).  Because the processes at the plant are regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) Risk Management Program (RMP) and are also subject to OSHA PSM, this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program.

Employee Participation:  Active employee participation and involvement in the development and implementation of the Coalgate/Tupelo Gas Plant's PSM program is an important step toward achieving the objective to prevent and minimize the consequences of a catastrophic release of toxic, reactive, flammable or explosive chemicals.  Employee involvement will help to ensure that all perspectives regarding PSM are considered, and that the best ideas are implemented.  Open communications are encouraged between supervisors and employees regarding safety and health issues.  At the Coalgate/Tupelo Gas Plant employee involvement in safety issues is strongly promoted through existing programs.  These programs include Unit Safety Teams (which are made up of a cross section of employees and management), regularly scheduled safety meetings, tail-gate safety meetings, Hazard Communication, Safety Suggestion forms, and special training programs (such as emergency response training, first aid, etc.).

Process Safety Information:  Complete and accurate written process safety information (PSI) concerning process chemicals, process technology, and process equipment is essential to an effective PSM and RMP program and to completing and maintaining a process hazard analysis (PHA).  The PSI will provide important input to the operators; the team performing the PHA; those in charge of training; contractors; those conducting pre-startup safety reviews; and those in charge of updating the emergency preparedness plans.  Proce

ss safety information is readily available to all employees.  There are a variety of technical documents kept at the Coalgate/Tupelo Gas Plant that are used to help maintain safe operations of the process.  These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, as well as equipment design basis/configuration information.  Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDSs).

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA): There is a comprehensive program at the Coalgate/Tupelo Gas Plant to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage them.  The facility primarily uses the Hazardous Operations (HAZOP) technique to perform these evaluations.  The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience in addition to engineering expertise.  The team identifies and evaluates hazards of each process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, when the team believes such measurements are necessary.  Periodic reviews of each process are conducted at least every 5 years and will continue on this schedule until the process is no longer operating.

Operating Procedures:  Coalgate/Tupelo Gas Plant maintains written procedures that address the different modes of processing operations, such as startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, normal shutdown, and initial startup of a new process.  These procedures provide guidance for experienced operators and also provide the basis for training new operators.  Operating procedures are periodically reviewed at least annually so that they can be certified as current and accurate.  The review and certif

ication process involves both operators and technical staff.

Training:  In addition to training on specific operating procedures, there is a comprehensive basic training program for all employees involved in operations.  New employees receive basic training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are at an acceptable level.  This refresher training is conducted at least every 3 years to ensure that the appropriate level of training is maintained.  All the training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training.

Contractors:  Coalgate/Tupelo uses contractors to supplement its work force during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities.  Because some contractors work or near process equipment, there are procedures in place to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have appropriate skills, (3) are aware of the hazards of the workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site specific safety rules, and (6) inform gas plant personnel of any hazards that they find during their work.  This training and awareness is accomplished by providing contractors with orientation sessions pertaining to these key points.

Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR):  A PSSR is conducted at the Coalgate/Tupelo Gas Plant on any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information.  The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service.  This review provides one additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready.  The PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves as a quality assurance function by requiring verification that acciden

t prevention program requirements are properly implemented.

Mechanical Integrity:  There are well establish practices and procedures at the Coalgate/Tupelo Gas Plant for maintaining process equipment.  The basic aspects of this program include (1) training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting equipment deficiencies when identified and (5) applying quality assurance measurements.  In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process.

Safe Work Practices:  Coalgate/Tupelo has long standing safe work practices in place to help ensure workers and process safety.  Examples of these include (1) control of entry/presence/exit of support personnel, (2) lockout/tagout procedures to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous substances before process piping and equipment is opened, (4) a permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities (e.g. hot work), and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space.  These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

Management of Change:  There is a comprehensive system at the Coalgate/Tupelo Gas Plant to manage changes to all covered processes.  This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to ensure that adequate controls have not been compromised by the change.  Where appropriate, chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information are updated, and operations and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training associated with the change

.

Incident Investigation:  All incidents at the Coalgate/Tupelo Gas Plant that result in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss or personnel injury are promptly investigated.  The goal of each investigation is to gather the facts, determine the root cause, and develop corrective action to prevent the reoccurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a reoccurrence, and forwards these results to the business management team for resolution and implementation.

Compliance Audits:  To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, the Coalgate/Tupelo Gas Plant periodically conducts an audit to determine whether procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented.  Compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years.  Both hourly and staff personnel participate as audit team members.  The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to Coalgate/Tupelo Gas Plant management for resolution and implementation.  Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audits are retained on file.

Five-Year Accident History

No incident resulting in onsite or offsite impacts from a hydrocarbon release has occurred at Coalgate/Tupelo within the last five years.  Although we take pride in that record, we also place daily emphasis on our prevention and safety program to ensure that the record continues.



Emergency Response Program

In the event of an emergency involving our natural gas liquid extraction facility, it is our policy to follow our Emergency Action Plan (EAP), which has been reviewed with the Coalgate/Tupelo County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and accepted by the Emergency Management District Direc

tor.  The EAP and the facility's emergency response policy have also been discussed with the local fire departments and members of the fire departments have conducted comprehensive inspections of  the Plant.

Activation of this emergency response plan sets in motion a pre-planned series of events that notify all area emergency response agencies.  This is done using the 911 system, which is channeled through the Coalgate/Tupelo County Sheriff's Department.  Once notified, all agencies and personnel assemble at predetermined staging areas with representatives from each agency reporting to the Central Command Post (CP).  The contingency plan that had been developed as part of the EAP is then followed using trained industry personnel, along with other emergency response personnel from responding agencies, as needed.

Each employee at Coalgate/Tupelo is issued with their own individual copy of the EAP when they are initially hired, and are then subsequently provided with any updates and revisions that made to the Plan.  In addition all operators at the Coalgate/Tupelo Gas Plant have had the appropriate emergency response training mandated by the OSHA standard.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

There are currently no planned changes to improve safety.  Rather, the company believes that diligent compliance with our RMP Prevention Program forms the framework that allows for the continued to improvement to the level of safety at Coalgate/Tupelo.  Some of the key components of the program that will help maintain and, where applicable, improve safety are:

?    The Management of Change provisions ensure that we consider the potential safety and health impacts of any change we make to process chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures.

?    The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) provisions serve as a tool to ensure continual evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in our safety standards.

?    The Mechanical Integrity provisions ensure that process

equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous release thereby serving as an integral part of our safety program.

?    Internal and third party compliance audits will ensure that we maintain and increase our level of safety protection.
